title: Losing Your Job Without Losing Your Home
sub_head: Mortgage-default insurance can induce private lenders to expand access to home financing by families of modest means.
body:
In “Lost Your Job? You Shouldn’t Have to Lose Your Home” (op-ed. Nov. 25), Arthur B. Laffer and Alan M. Dershowitz describe a “simple, effective new product . . . lender-paid insurance that will seamlessly cover mortgage payments in the event of involuntary unemployment” as a means for homeowners to avoid the devastation of losing their homes through foreclosure.
Kudos to the private insurance provider that is patenting new technology to trigger this insurance product’s benefits via 50 state unemployment-benefit systems. This product, however, is far from new. MI Plus was first launched in 2004 by the Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency—a state-sponsored agency comparable to the Federal Housing Administration. MI Plus has helped over a thousand Massachusetts homeowners avoid foreclosure after losing their jobs and incomes.
This Massachusetts borrower-benefit insurance has passed the actuarial test—at a zero incremental premium over the Massachusetts Mortgage Insurance Fund’s standard lender-paid insurance premium which covers the lender’s foreclosure-related losses. Avoiding a homeowner’s foreclosure is mitigating a mortgage lender’s loss. This product has great promise—if state governments will cooperate.
As a former mortgage insurance risk-management executive and consultant for an international management consulting firm, I have helped senior housing-finance officials in over a dozen developing countries examine how mortgage-default insurance can induce private lenders to expand access to home financing by families of modest means. Many expressed particular interest in the Massachusetts foreclosure-avoidance model, which provides complementary credit-insurance benefits to lender and borrower.
Roger Blood
